job_title: Software Engineer in New York, NY
pros: This is the real deal: an authentically mission-driven startup with staggering competency from the bottom up. Leadership values its staff on a par with the mission itself (collegiality and impact take equal footing among the company values). The extraordinary crew of Enveritas are brilliant, down-to-earth, committed professionals who support one another and believe in their work. As an engineer at a company whose product is not primarily technological, I am constantly learning from my colleagues, am given room to innovate, and feel valued every day while applying my expertise towards something more fulfilling (to me) than any app or algorithm.
cons:
This is a small, very horizontal startup with a giant mission. As such, staff must be largely self-organizing, with a high degree of personal responsibility. You will be called on to hustle sometimes, or make radical context switches, which can be jarring for some (and exhilarating for others). Operations are global (think: timezones, languages), with many moving parts (think motorcycles fording rivers to get to a data connection) and strict timelines, so good communication skills are a must (even among the engineers :).

Speaking specifically to the (very small, take note) engineering team: some days are a whole lot of brick-laying. Because our products are mostly internal, not everything gets the polish it deserves— prioritization follows operational and business needs, which can be disappointing for the perfectionist.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
I'm a mission-driven person who cares deeply that the work I do contributes toward making an impact on the world. The integrity with which the teams work with is unmatched in my 15+ years of professional experience—it's really a joy to be working with such a nimble, smart group.

It's also a young company, and for me, the "fit" in the size of the team is great for my personal interests. I like working in small teams of 4-8 people, without the formal structure and policies that are present in large corporations.
cons: As a non-profit, there's not financial equity or IPOs around the corner. This isn't to say my salary isn't entirely reasonable--I'm honestly fine with it!--but someone coming in who expects crazy perks should understand that the company is a non-profit.
